issue.title: Laser and stereo data misalignment (unrelated to diff between visual and collision geom)

content.raw:
I can confirm this. LIDAR points seem to have a mean range that is 6-10cm closer (varies) to the sensor than it actually should be. I'm attaching two screenshots, one with the robot looking down at the ground with stereo correctly showing the ground plane at a mean height of ~0cm while lidar (red points) measures a height of ~10cm, and the other showing the measurement offset using a dumpster placed in front of the robot:

Attaching failed so here they are:

* http://i.imgur.com/0AWKs5l.png
* http://i.imgur.com/s5DG46B.png

issue.title: Laser and stereo data misalignment (unrelated to diff between visual and collision geom)

content.raw: This issue seems to have appeared in the last month. The version of gazebo I used in March didn't have this.
content.html: This issue seems to have appeared in the last month. The version of gazebo I used in March didn't have this.

issue.title: Laser and stereo data misalignment (unrelated to diff between visual and collision geom)

content.raw: Might be related to [gazebo issue #503](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/503/), which suggests that laser ranges are measured from minimum range rather than the sensor origin.  That would produce scans that are too short.  In the case of the Hokuyo laser in the MultiSense-SL, each beam would be too short by 10cm.  If you substract 10cm from each beam, does the data look right?
content.html: Might be related to gazebo issue #503, which suggests that laser ranges are measured from minimum range rather than the sensor origin. That would produce scans that are too short. In the case of the Hokuyo laser in the MultiSense-SL, each beam would be too short by 10cm. If you substract 10cm from each beam, does the data look right?

issue.title: Laser and stereo data misalignment (unrelated to diff between visual and collision geom)

content.raw:
I changed gazebo/sensors/RaySensor.cc to add on "+ 0.1;"
    double range = this->laserShape->GetRange(j * this->GetRayCount() + i) + 0.1;

... and that seems to be it. ground returns are correctly on the ground with this change and i also compared with some objects in the scene e.g. the vehicle.

Where is that set?
content.html:
I changed gazebo/sensors/RaySensor.cc to add on "+ 0.1;" double range = this->laserShape->GetRange(j * this->GetRayCount() + i) + 0.1;

... and that seems to be it. ground returns are correctly on the ground with this change and i also compared with some objects in the scene e.g. the vehicle.

Where is that set?

issue.title: Laser and stereo data misalignment (unrelated to diff between visual and collision geom)

content.html:
Here's a patch to try:

diff -r 1a69666680ab gazebo/physics/MultiRayShape.cc
--- a/gazebo/physics/MultiRayShape.cc   Sat Apr 13 18:17:01 2013 -0700
+++ b/gazebo/physics/MultiRayShape.cc   Sun Apr 14 16:53:55 2013 -0700
@@ -113,7 +113,7 @@
     gzthrow(stream.str());
   }

-  return this->rays[_index]->GetLength();
+  return this->GetRangeMin() + this->rays[_index]->GetLength(); 
 }

 //////////////////////////////////////////////////

It'll take a bit of work to get the tests updated to adapt to this change.

Laser and stereo data misalignment (unrelated to diff between visual and collision geom)

content.raw:
My compilers say I don't have a GetRangeMin() method.

I dont work off of head. i'll need to download head and compile it to.

issue.title: Laser and stereo data misalignment (unrelated to diff between visual and collision geom)

content.html:
Sorry, pasted the wrong version; take 2:

diff -r 1a69666680ab gazebo/physics/MultiRayShape.cc
--- a/gazebo/physics/MultiRayShape.cc   Sat Apr 13 18:17:01 2013 -0700
+++ b/gazebo/physics/MultiRayShape.cc   Sun Apr 14 17:06:29 2013 -0700
@@ -113,7 +113,7 @@
     gzthrow(stream.str());
   }

-  return this->rays[_index]->GetLength();
+  return this->rangeElem->GetValueDouble("min") + this->rays[_index]->GetLength(); 
 }

 //////////////////////////////////////////////////

That's still not quite right, as it produces ranges greater than the max. Once I understand how the ray sensor works, I'll put in a proper fix.

issue.title: Laser and stereo data misalignment (unrelated to diff between visual and collision geom)

content.raw:
That seems to do the trick. The returns seem to be the same as adding on 0.1m

FYI: there is an method called GetMinRange() 
There was none called GetRangeMin()

Thanks! (signing off, its pretty late where i am)
content.html:
That seems to do the trick. The returns seem to be the same as adding on 0.1m

FYI: there is an method called GetMinRange() There was none called GetRangeMin()

issue.title: Laser and stereo data misalignment (unrelated to diff between visual and collision geom)

content.raw:
Fixed by [gazebo pull request #449](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/449), related to [gazebo issue #503](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/503).

Fix expected to appear in Gazebo 1.6.3 and 1.7
content.html:
Fixed by gazebo pull request #449, related to gazebo issue #503.

Fix expected to appear in Gazebo 1.6.3 and 1.7
